Bought a paperwhite pot from us and have had them already bloom? Grab a pack of replacement bulbs from our holiday popup shop @workskennettsquare !

5 bulbs in each bag, we order Inbal, my favorite variety- as it’s slightly less scented than the common Ziva for those who need a lighter scent. Grow in rocks or soil. Paperwhites are not fussy !

You can keep your existing bulbs for next year, just let their foliage die back and then cut it off to the top of the bulb. Swap out the new bulbs and water in! You will have new blooms in 2 to 3 weeks!

I love having paperwhites all over the house in the holiday season especially when I’m missing my flowers outside! Paperwhites are always our top seller every year! 👏🏼
#paperwhites #chescopa #tfaoholidayshop #shopksq #grow

Spotlight on Amaryllis!
People are often apprehensive to try growing an amaryllis but hopefully you will gain confidence when I tell you that they are very easy!

These winter flowers such as amaryllis and paperwhites WANT to bloom, and often they will do it with almost no help from us.

We offer single and triple potted amaryllis, wax and moss covered amaryllis, and single bagged amaryllis for sale every holiday. There’s an amaryllis for ANY type of grower/appreciator/gardener.

For those who want to do NOTHING and still get a big bloom-the WAX or MOSS amaryllis is for you.  No water, no dirt, minimal light and you will still get a plethora of blooms from these babies.

For those who want the full package but not to do it themselves, our potted single or triple amaryllis are the way to go. They make GREAT hostess gifts - just set into an area with a little light, not even sunlight, and give it a little weekly watering and that’s it. You’ll enjoy blooms through February most years.

For those who already have a selection of containers and the gardening skills - pick up an amaryllis bulb and plant it yourself at home! A little rocks, some soil, and the bulb is all you need. We also give you full instructions to make it even easier.

I really miss the flowers in winter and having paperwhites and amaryllis around all through Jan and Feb really keep my spirits up.

Pickup a bulb, a pot, or a waxed/mossed baby this Thursday, Friday and even SAT til 2pm at @workskennettsquare - your last chance for a gift or a hostess goodie before the holiday hits us. If you’re closer to the farm & want to pickup here during the week just drop me a DM. 

Have you had the joy of experiencing giant amaryllis blooms in January yet? If not, make this year your year to do it!🌱❤️🌲 #amaryllis #tfaoholidayshop #chescopa #brandywinevalley

I grew these in my basement! Last year was our first year forcing tulips in winter, and this year I'm taking what I learned and making improvements. Forcing tulips isn't as easy as buying pre chilled bulbs and then throwing them into a warm room. There is a lot of trial, error, calculations, specifically knowing when they went into cooling, how warm they like to grow, what levels to keep humidity at, how to deal with pests, and bacteria/funguses etc etc. I learned some on my own, but my base foundation of knowledge was from @thetulipworkshop - highly recommend Linda and Emily's class if you want to work to create your own forcing program.

This year I was trying to hit Christmas with our own tulips - which is a tough feat because most tulips come to us without 100% of their cooling even if they have had 'most of it'. So we still have to finish cooling, and root them, and then grow them out-and most of our bulb vendors don't even ship us the bulbs until November. 🫣 Therefore- Timing is really tight for Christmas. 

But WE MADE IT! With one variety of tulips- thankfully we had 3 trays of them hit at the right time, allowing me for the first time ever to put our a good amt of our OWN STEMS into our 100% domestic Christmas bunches & it gives me more data for next year.

The rest of the varieties will be ready heading into the New Year- so anyone up for some New Years celebration tulips? 😉 AND we are already working on our Valentine's Day ❤️ tulips- we have over 1500 rooting right now in our cooler.

I love having flowers in winter though so I'm happy to get them any old time. The best part to me, is that we have figured out how to utilize our existing systems already in place so we are adding relatively little extra power to the equation - just playing with the way we already have things setup for other wintering elements on the farm.

So cheers 🥂 to learning new things and pushing the boundaries! I'm so excited about growing this program in years to come! #pagrown #tulips #thetulipworkshop #wintergrowing

Winter Box Item

I’m a little slow over here and still have things to share, so here we go! 

Fancy daffodil bulbs from @thefarmatoxford. When I reached out to Mara about including bulbs in the winter boxes she was totally on board. She always curated the most beautiful selection of bulbs, corms, tubers and more. These bulbs can be planted either directly into the ground or in a planter. I was hoping everyone could enjoy these, regardless of their living circumstances. Enjoying spring flowers always lifts my mood and are such a welcome to change in season. 

Here is a bit about Mara’s farm: 

The Farm at Oxford is a boutique cut flower farm in Chester County, Pennsylvania, growing and selling cut stems locally within a 30mile radius to designers, florists and retail customers, and we also provide the knowledge, plants, bulbs and roots to gardeners across the US to grow your own.  I am inspired by the unique and challenging, and as long as the ground is not frozen, you can typically find me outside digging in the dirt or in the workshop playing with flowers.

Mara has been my flower and houseplant dealer for many many years now. She is a wealth of information and knowledge, not to mention beautiful things. Go give her some love. She also ships! So if you want to snag some high quality flower goodness, sign up for her newsletter.

Winter treasures🌸 -having tulips in January now feels routine- though this crop does take a lot of time & special care to tend - more so than field tulips which just do their thing with little help from me. We have to manage rooting, temps, disease, watering, timing. We are now pulling and storing ready tulips in our cooler with bulb on for our Valentines bunches. The bulb continues to feed the flower until we need the stem. If you need a winter pick me up- ad hoc bunches are always available in our online shop for pickup through the week! Flower farming is such a labor of love.

Sure- arranging or making bunches is a fun pretty part of it- but it takes months of planning, planting, tending, then harvesting, processing to get to that beautiful product you see at the end.

Along the way, there are failed crops, insects, weeds, droughts or floods, and countless other pitfalls.

But the end product somehow makes up for all of those stressful, sweaty months. I always joke around that farmers are crazy- deciding to go into business with mother nature - oof 😂😂 but here we are 💪🏼 🌸❤️ #flowerfarm #pagrown #grow #gardening #flowerstalking #broll #chesco

It’s almost dahlia season and we are busy little bees over here working on our tubers. A few have asked us for an update on a potential tuber sale... it’s still TBD on if we will be having a named sale this year. Just so much going on!

However I know we WILL be offering mixed bags - we grow over 80 varieties of dahlias - including some very coveted ones and ANY extras we have over our needed ones for our field go into these mixed bags. It’s a great way to get some fun varieties that we use for cuts for an affordable price. Keep a watch out for this on the website soon.

HOWEVER - in the meantime, we can feel spring coming a mile away. So to have a little fun, I wanted to put together something fun to brighten our spirits while we wait for spring!

Up for grabs are three mixed bags of tubers, one pack of 5 each- to 3 individuals total-winners will be randomly chosen.

Included in these bags will be a few basics and a few of our more coveted varieties-camano zoe, mission gypsy, BQ alan, peanut brittle, odyssey, rock run ashley, PNC, salish twilight girl, orange globe or others- we grow all of those and more.

It’s a fun way to get started with a little dahlia patch of your own! Also included will be our dahlia growing instructions- a full 2 pages of how to take the best care of these babies!

HOW TO ENTER: go to the link in our profile here and enter to win on the form that pops up. Also be sure to opt in to be added to our newsletter update email list so you get first notice if we do run a sale! That’s it! One entry per email address in the US for shipping purposes only.

We will notify you via email if you are a winner- note we will never DM you on here or ask you to fill anything else out via DM (scammers will though!). Whenever in doubt, drop me a DM on if you receive anything fishy. Please share & tag a friend who might want some dahlia bbs of their own! #pagrown #dahlias #growyourown #flowerfarmers #wannabeflowerfarmer

I know everyone wants to know when we are having our tuber sale!

Here is our situation this year. A farmer friend who had a tough year lost her entire field of dahlias as a result. As a dahlia farmer, this is a nightmare we all think about happening to us, not being able to get your tubers out of the field in time or your cooler malfunctioning in winter - and I know a few friends who have gone through it! It is so tough and given how crazy the sales are nowadays, unless you have people willing to help you out, you might be SOL. So instead of doing a named sale this year, we will help her replenish a large portion of her lost field by selling her the bulk of our available tubers to get her back on her feet.

This means that we will not be having a big sale this year. I can’t say I’m sad because, man those sales are stressful! However, I know so many of you love our dahlias and still want to support us & get yourself some tubers, so we will still be able to offer our mixed collections to you this year!

A bag of 5 tubers, unnamed but normally identifiable upon blooming. It’s a great way to get some special varieties for less- and any extras we have will go into these bags. We also typically don’t divide all the way down into single tubers- leaving them in small clumps to be on the safe side- so often times you get more than 5 eyes in each bag, and may end up with a few extra tubers as a result.

These mixed bags are live on our website and will ship/be avail for pickup in late April/early May - we ship across the US too. Tap the link in profile and select ‘dahlia tubers’ to shop. 

In the meantime, enjoy this fun new reel (I had to use this audio once I heard it) showcasing the rainbow of colors our dahlias come in! #pagrown #chestercounty #dahlias #dahliafarm

Today was a good day. Today was the first day I could FEEL spring in the air.

We have had a lot of warm days and cold days over the last few months with this weird warmer PNW weather- but today was the first day I could just feel spring.

I finally planted our cold weather veg & finished cleaning up the veg garden, pruning the blackberries and training them the way Matt showed me.

Our veggie garden brings me so much joy. We started it in 2020 during quarantine with Matt @msumatadoor - one of our good friends, then he moved a few states away last year and now the job of tending to the quite-large-for-a-small-family garden falls entirely to me, but it is really something I love to do. Farming the flowers is obviously something I love as well but in a different way. The veggie garden isn't required to pay our mortgage or feed us - like the flower business does. The veg garden is just for joy.

I harvested the almost-last of our 2023 winter basement tulips and they are bundled together with anemone and coming to you tomorrow at @workskennettsquare timorrow! The container gardens are all made and getting picked up this weekend by customers. I'm working on our own container gardens this weekend too.

We leave on Tuesday for our first big trip since 2019- we have an amazing farm sitter thankfully for the kiddo and all the animals, and Rhi and Kendell have the flowers under control- but there is a ton to get done before we take off, and I am simultaneously excited and terrified.

But spring is in the air. Nature won’t wait. And this is our last weekend of 'calm' - because I know when we get back home from our getaway- spring season will be well underway. The peonies have already broken ground (in March!), the tulips are growing, the daffs are unfurling their petals. We are about to be in it and I really can't wait for everything 2023 season will bring.

PS 🌸🐣 limited quantity of Easter bunches are live on the website for pre-order. Don’t miss your chance to snag a holiday bloom bouquet! 
#chestercounty #pagrown #kennettsquare #brandywinevalley #farmlife

Today was the first hellebore harvest of many! We have over 2000 planted on the farm and they are a crucial crop for us at this time of the year. The popular sentiment is to wait until the stamens have dropped and the bloom is mature to harvest for best vase life. Otherwise - they often droop within a day.

However, thanks to an insta video I found a few years ago (cannot find the insta name because I want to tag!!) -I learned this trick, and now religiously use it to harvest immature hellebores with great success. This gives us a much longer harvest window with them- usually from late March thru Mother’s Day.

-Lightly score the stem in a vertical fashion from middle of stem to bottom- hellebores are dense stems & have a hard time taking water in. I don’t DEEPLY score or cut all the way thru-learned this lesson because then often the stem curls up inti itself and it’s hard to use them to arrange with. So the lighter score is crucial.
-Then I immerse them in very hot water, not boiling just super hot tap water, for up to a few hours, make sure to get as far up the stem as you can and be sure to immerse the ENTIRE scored area or else air bubbles might get in.
-I let them sit for a few hours like this and then refresh the water using regular cool tap water and let them condition for up to 12 hours.

Doing this -I have 99% success rate with every stem I cut. On any droopers, redo the process if you want. I harvest them the day before I need them for an order -this way I can see within the day if any fail. If they don’t fail I know they will last up to 2 weeks in a vase for my customer.

We love to mix them with daffodils, tulips, and foliage in our early bouquets-and they will be a prominent feature in next weekends Easter preorders. The first harvest is always SO EXCITING for me- and today I really felt the joy cutting them and processing them after a long year waiting to see their beautiful faces in our vases again. Enjoy the beauty❤️ #helleboreflowers #helleboreappreciationsociety #hellebore #lentenrose 
#flowerfarm #grow #garden #loveflowers

I meant to share this weeks ago, and now our daffodil season is over. However, this tip is evergreen and will always be useful if you grow daffodils!

How we harvest: We pull the stem, we don’t cut. This gives us a longer stem length by pulling a few inches out from underground, leaves the foliage on to add energy back to the bulb as it dies back & also keeps things neater as not as much sap tends to drain from a pulled vs cut stem. Don’t forget to still let your stem drain out for a couple hours before arranging with other flowers for best vase life.

How to pull: some varieties definitely pull better than others - slide your fingers down the stem to near the dirt, grasp and tug. You’ll feel a pop and the stem is free. It was also so much faster to harvest this way - I can do 100 in less than 5 minutes, and you don’t need any special tools - just your hands.

Apparently the sap can sometimes be an irritant to our skin, so be sure to wash your hands after you harvest. #daffodils #narcissus #pagrown #grow #garden #springbulbs #flowerfarmer

We are down to our last few peony varieties blooming - did you know that there are 6 to 7 weeks of bloom time in peony season? Whenever people find out that we grow peonies -.they inevitably tell me that they have one in the yard that only blooms for just a week. How I make rose syrup❤️ We have hundreds of roses planted on our flower farm and I try to make syrup every year to prolong the enjoyment of the first rose flush.

—>> Gather 2 cups of fresh petals or 1cup of dried. Be sure to use roses that are organic or not sprayed with any chemicals. The more heavily scented the better, also the darker the petals, the more colorful the syrup.
—>> Wash the roses to remove any dust or pests. Pull petals off, removing stamen and any green- it will be bitter. Pour hot water over the petals and let them steep on a very low temp, barely a simmer for up to an hour. I try to use as little heat as possible because I feel it saps the flavor to boil it.
—>> In the last 5minutes, add a cup or more of sugar to taste, you can use honey if you prefer - it will slightly modify flavor, let simmer for a few more minutes to melt the sugars. You can also add a few dried petals of hibiscus to color the syrup even more-especially if you used lighter roses- you won’t taste it and it just makes a darker pink syrup.
—>> Strain out petals, and let syrup cool. Store in glass jars in a fridge. I love making a few extra jars for friends! Use within a few weeks.

Syrup is all about taste, so experiment! You can add other flavoring if you want such as a bit of vanilla bean. Make a summer mocktail with syrup and seltzer, or a cocktail with vodka and gin and a seltzer or st germain. You can also drizzle over angel food or pound cake or mix it into an ice cream. Rose season is fleeting but having the sweet scent in syrup over the next few weeks always reminds me of my childhood! #rosesyrup #roses #pagrown #edibleflowers #ediblegarden

We grow many of our thousands of lisianthus in a close partnership with another farm nearby - she has the infrastructure (heated greenhouse, labor, many tunnels) to support the quantities that such a large, fussy crop requires & this year was a real challenge. She had a surprising serious soil issue pop up - and some of our plants were dying. Throw in the cold temps & dry weather and we were getting worried about our largest summer crop coming to fruition properly. It would mean thousands of dollars in lost revenue, plugs we brought in, and a waste of space, energy, time.

Even though this is our 5th year growing summer crops this way - things are not always the same every year. It’s been a challenging year for many small farms - so this first full bucket of lisi we cut yesterday felt like a real treasure. It’s the start of lisi season-finally! We bring in thousands of plugs every February just for our summer customers-lisi is a very long growing crop from seed to bloom!

Our super special varieties like blue chateau, pale blushy pinks, and the ruffly lavender beauties are some of my favorite things about July.

Thanks as always to @farmerbaileyplugs for the stellar starts and hard work & research that allows us to get such beautiful varieties beyond the typical bright purples and magentas that create our signature palettes. 

There are many hands behind the final product coming from any farm & I’m very thankful for all of our hands in the chain. Find these special babes tucked into @workskennettsquare bunches today-Sun 11-5 & do a cheer for some much needed heat finally pushing things along. #lisianthus #summer #grow

Our micro wedding packages are my favorites. For years, we were asked to do full service weddings, but they are not my specialty & so we always referred them out to some of my talented design friends. However, during covid years, we developed a wedding package that also comes with some professional design elements - and this year we will deliver 15+ of these packages to bridal customers.

Today was Ani’s wedding pickup- her initial inquiry was my favorite type- broad and willing to let us do our thing. My choice of absolutely everything..the only ask is that everything is color coordinated to work together (of course!!). Everything we use is locally grown & in-season.

I designed her bridal bouquet around the summer sherbert inspiration photos she emailed us - it was obvious she loved the bouncy look of feverfew and cosmos as they were in every photo she sent- so I was glad to tuck those in for her (if we are able to include special touches we do - we always pay attention to the details in the photos you send us!).

Her bulk buckets that she and her bridesmaids will turn into centrepieces and jars for her tables are color coordinated to her bridal bouquet. We even included foliage for everything to round out nicely visually.

One of the best parts of the exchange this morning as I helped her load in the buckets was that we had done this same package for a few of her friends over the last few years as well and that she felt comfortable doing the same. Brings me such joy and reminds me why we do what we do! Happy wedding weekend Ani ❤️ and thank you for your trust. Find more about our wedding packages on the website- now booking 2024🌸

This is what it looks like when dahlias are left in high temps for days with lack of fresh water. These are the dahlia share bouquets that were not picked up yet when our retail space, worKS, closed suddenly on Saturday due to safety concerns about the escaped prisoner from the local Chester County prison.

Now the hunt for him is on day 6- and all weekend I thought BOTH about our sad little orders stuck in the building as temps climbed over 92 - AND about the locals stuck in their homes on lockdown, with police escorts into neighborhoods, helicopters circling at all hours of the day, and not knowing what comes next.

This is the reality of farming AND the reality of small business. When you are looking at the risk assessment for your crop that year, something like this was not in the planning. We will compost many hundreds of dollars this weekend in stems that didn’t make it to the customer - and while it may not sound like much to some, it is a big deal to our little farm business where margins are razor slim to begin with.

It feels wrong to think on lost sales or product when so many people were in a state of stress and fear all weekend- but that is the reality of working with a perishable product. It is trite to be single minded-  since I feel sadness for the situation that our local community is in, and sadness at the manifestation of the stress in an actual visual representation of what we saw when we picked up the flowers today.

Crossing everything that this jackal is caught soon - and sending love to everyone in the perimeters hunkered down and unsure what is coming next. Stay safe all❤️ & thank you to those non-locals who reached out to us asking about our safety! While our retail business is right in the thick of it- the farm is 15min away.

🌸 SHARE recipients, look for an email from me on a potential Plan B for this coming wkd- Harvests don’t wait - so we have to plan NOW just in case- again dealing with farming & perishables and commitments that don’t wait❤️ Thanks so much for your patience with us as we navigate through this unprecedented situation. #farming

Anemone dahlias- only a single row of petals and usually a center that puffs out - super adorable but known to have a short vase life. However, if you harvest time right when the petals open before the center starts to pop - we typically can get about the same vase life as other dahlias aka 3-5 days depending on treatment. I learned this last year. And even though we grow only a couple anemone style dahlias - I love being able to use them more reliably in designs because there is nothing like their softer look & movement. Did you know this? Comment below 👇🏼 ❤️ #dahlia #grow #farmlife #pagrown

Every flower grower’s nightmare. When a pallet strap breaks and tulips spill everywhere.

Tulips and daffodils and many other bulbs including corms, dahlia tubers etc look the SAME when they are dormant. Sometimes there are small characteristics that can help you identify one vs the other (shinier skin, or a darker skin, or sometimes a darker tuber or a reddish tuber)- but sometimes there are not!

Yesterday during transport of one of our big bulb orders (13000 bulbs!) back to our farm (by my husband, yes I’m still keeping him)- the pallet stability failed and we had a little oopsie.

Seeing this at first, I felt completely sick to my stomach. It looked much worse than it ended up being. I’m a ‘fixer’ by nature, so I got to work figuring out how to best make sense of the mess while keeping as much as 2/3 of the order intact - I am so grateful it was not a worse mishap- we will be planting some ‘mixed’ tulips in the field but most of the order was salvageable-WHEW. I had so many farmers messaging me the screaming emoji- and so many ‘been there done that’ comments too- I guess it happens to everyone once (hopefully just once)- and I guess after 9 years of buying bulk bulbs- we were overdue!😆

Don’t worry- all these bulbs still get planted - nothing is wasted- AND thankfully only a tiny portion of this was for our retail bulb collection orders - so no major crisis - I’m able to switch gears without too much trouble.

This is no one’s ‘fault’- it was rainy yesterday causing distraction while loading and packing; and a longer drive than typical - but always a good reminder to check all those straps and add extra security for the future for these big heavy pallets.

But yeah - after this we poured ourselves a stiff old fashioned, got takeout and went to bed early- saying a big ole GOODBYE to Friday🙈 - today is a new day! #flowergrower #flowerfarming #farming #tulips #gardeninglife

Growing dahlias in hot humid southeast PA is not for the faint of heart.
 
We plant them in May & the tending begins, dedicating about 15 hours a week to helping them grow upright, staking, weeding, feeding, watering - these things get LEAFY here even when we don’t add nitrogen. I’m not sure if it’s a stress reaction, but compare our fields here to the sparse plants you see in coastal CA/WA where the mild weather and cooler temps are perfect for growing dahlias, we wonder WHY ours are so dang big. I would love a smaller plant loaded with lots of blooms, but here we get giant fat leafy plants that start making blooms later. Only right now, the last two weeks of the entire season with the dahlias do we start to see them REALLY shine.

I’ve grown dahlias for 10 years and commercially for 9 years. Every time I visit friends’ fields in CA - I am left wondering - WHY DO I GROW DAHLIAS IN PA- literally questioning my life decisions as they are one of our biggest crops & we invest a lot of time and money into them. But then fall comes, and allll the hard work is really worth it when you see how glorious they can be.

This post is almost a reminder to myself - my next-July self- that don’t worry the good times will come! Your work is not in vain. And I say this to everyone else too. Our field has really never looked so good- thanks to the endless efforts of our small team here but especially @kendellpie who joined us last year from Longwood & probably spent the entire season questioning HER life decisions as she endlessly staked and tied and worried why the dahlias didn’t look like Longwoods’. This year we all doubled down on making the dahlias the best they could be & I am so proud of how amazing the field looks. Everyone give three cheers to Kendell for challenging us to be better!

There are a few days left for YOU to enjoy the dahlias- a few you pick days left.  I MAY add more days or do one big group day- depending on weather forecast and how things look on Monday after a potential 40 degrees- so if you missed out -grab a spot and a friend and come pick yourself a bucket in our field. #pagrown #dahliafield #grow #blooooms #flowerfarm

A few years ago we grew our own ginger and turmeric for the first time - and now whenever we are able to find starts - I tuck a few plants into the farm veg garden.

I’m no expert at it, and we don’t have the heated GH setup to start our own roots in late winter the way you are supposed to- they need a long period of growth- but thankfully our friends @bluestembotanicals sold starts this year of ginger, and we got some blue turmeric from @bakercreekseeds (TBD on that harvest!).

These were planted in our outdoor veggie garden as sprouted starts in early June in SE PA 6b - hot and humid in the summer-we plant shallow and keep adding soil on top as the tops grow-and harvested today November 1. I planted 4 little baby starts and this was my harvest today. We put a few in our hoop as an experiment but so far the outdoor veg vs the hoop wins hands down.

If you have never had FRESH ginger, you have no idea what you are missing! Just like garden grown garlic, it is tender and soft and so flavorful. The ginger we get at a grocery store is many months old, probably almost OLDER than the ‘mother’ starts I put in the garden in June which are still tender if you slice into them.

Ginger has many health and medicinal benefits, but tonite I tossed some into a pot of water on the stove with fresh rosemary from the farm & made a simple syrup which I then turned into a honey bourbon lemon cocktail. Delish! 

What are your fave ways to use ginger?! Teas, soups, syrups, recipes, the options are endless. If you have ever wanted to experiment with growing your own ginger-I highly recommend it! #ginger #growyourfood #gardengrown #pagrown #medicinalherbs

A week ago our 1700 dahlia field froze. This week, we are working on cutting the string, taking the stakes out, pulling up the row fabric. Then, after all that is done, we will mow them down with the tractor. But even before the frost, we were double and triple checking tags, pulling diseased plants, and more to be ready. After we mow, we will start the big dig next Tuesday. I am thrilled to have some extra bodies help us that day, it makes the hard work go much more quickly when you are laughing with others as you pull clumps. While digging, we will make sure that we have crates, tags, etc on hand and log each variety- then pile them into our cooler in crates as high as a person to store thru the winter. It’s a huge job but the dahlias are precious- we have over 115 varieties, and a fair amount of ‘unicorns’. Stay tuned for BTS over the next week of our process! #dahlias #growyourown #flowerfarm #gardening #inmygarden #flowerfarmer

Let’s talk about evolution.

Born & raised in San Jose in the 70’s/80s- my first jobs were in corporate tech at 17. Maturing in that fluid environment taught me one thing- change is constant. My first ‘layoffs’ were at age 18 & quite often afterwards.

I became adaptable, unruffled, and resilient. This base prepared me for our PA move in 2013-and for farming in 2014. Farming is adaptation, resilience and hope - ‘next season will always be better.’ Over the last 10 yrs, we have seen the growth, dips and changes.

So now- let’s talk holiday shop- @workskennettsquare 2017- a huge hit with our locals. Every year, it grew. In 2019 we had our best holiday yet, leading me to even think about opening my own shop. Then-2020.

Things changed. People’s shopping habits changed. We adapted-but in perishables, decisions are from data a YEAR old. A lot changes in a year & some predictions were wrong. Since covid, we have seen a lot of wasted holiday products go into our compost pile- lost money- kept adapting.

2023. This year, we launched our smallest holiday popup shop ever. I wondered if I should address it-no one wants to be seen as ‘downsizing’ -but the reality -full transparency- is that 2023 was hard. For you all, for me, and many others. Everyone is squeezing their dollars a little tighter. For the first time in 10 years- I wondered about the future of our business. I’m adaptable, but your girl is also tired. Mom/wife/flower/farm life-my resilient heart is exhausted.

The future is a question not yet answered. BUT- holiday popup is still here- smaller but packed with faves. I will be restocking often. A big space packed w/goodies is very pictureque - BUT perishables NEED to have a quick turn so they don’t get wasted.

So friends- please tell your friends about our shop filled w/handmade plant & flower goods & about worKS ! There are still MANY locals who don’t know about this wonderful space that houses over 30 small LOCAL businesses. We NEED you this holiday season. Again this year- 90% of my shopping will be small business. If we don’t support one another, we won’t be here in a few years.

We really do appreciate you all more than you know. Much love❤️❤️

Yep it’s true! You can overwinter your dahlias in warmer zones- even down to zone 6 which is what our zone used to be (now we are rezoned as 7). Why wouldn’t you!? It saves time, labor, stress of storing the tubers through winter, it’s not that difficult to setup to overwinter, so I can absolutely see why gardeners and farmers are doing it!

Why don’t WE do it then? Well- we tried it a few years on and off - and it does work. How? You cut back the stalks to the ground, mound up 12” or so of leaves or natural materials-around here we have no shortage of leaves!- and then we tarped the entire thing with a big plastic tarp. Or you can tarp to the ground first, and then put leaves on it, however you choose. The two most important things are: 1. keeping them insulated in case of very cold temps, and 2. keeping too much water from saturating the ground and rotting them in a dormant state.

HOWEVER- why we don’t do it is fairly simple. We always experienced ‘some’ loss in the winter months, maybe 10%- and my OCD brain does not allow me to have random holes in our field. I also plant by color, so having choppy color sections bugged me all season. Yep it’s a control issue, I admit it!😅

I also felt as though the plants needed division even after a year, we can get some massive clumps in a season on some varieties. I noticed thinner stems and lower flower quality appearing much sooner in the season than from a divided tuber - and you are then digging a much larger clump 2-3 years down the line- which IMO makes dividing that much more of a daunting task, especially when it’s 1500 plants!

But yep you can do it. I encourage all of my garden lovers who grow dahlias to just overwinter, you don’t have to dig! It’s much easier to care for them in the ground while protected than in storage. But if you want to move things around or change the garden up, I recommend digging.

Do you overwinter? Do you dig? Share your tips and tricks. Some years, I wish we could just overwinter as it would maybe be easier, but we have our routine down and it works well for us! The beauty is that we can each decide what works best for us! 👏🏼👏🏼 #flowerfarm #dahlias

I’m no Martha - and I prefer to do as little extra work as possible during our busy season - so here is a quick tip on repurposing your fall planters/wood bushels into winter planters! We sold these cute wood fall bushels in early September. They bloomed their hearts out with rudbeckia, ivy, peppers, lysimachia and salvia, and now we we are left with the peppers, and the ivy and lysimachia which will come back in spring!

You could just toss the entire thing and I’m sure many do- however my favorite thing to do is just cut out the dead material, leaving the plants which come back for the next year. Then just stick your evergreens into the dirt in the planter along with the plants that are already there and camouflage everything underneath. I left the peppers because they are already dried and look cute and just added some winterberry for additional red.

In the spring, I will pull out the dead evergreens and add pansies and some other early flowers. By late March-the lysimachia and ivy will start greening up. By summer - chances are the bushel wood will be much more disintegrated- so will replace the entire thing with a fresh bushel - but this allows me to get an extra two seasons out of something that most people would consider a single use and the leftover wood can be burned in our summer bonfires & plants relocated to new planters! Enjoy! #holidaytips #winterplants #holidayfun #grow #reuse #sustainablegardening

Stem Topple - probably a term that most tulip buyers have not heard. It supposedly can happen when the humidity is too high in the growing room - but we sometimes get it even when our humidity is lower in our winter grow room (potential calcium deficiency!). While I usually can spot the signs before they topple & not give the stems to a customer- there are always going to be some missed stems that go out into the world. If your tulip does this and topples- don’t toss it. It still has plenty of life in it!! I took all of these that had toppled during growing-cut them down & put em in a cute short @magnoliahome vase. They still lasted six days in my kitchen window AND since tulips are phototropic and continue to grow taller and move towards light after they are cut-these ended up working perfectly for my vase! Save the tulips 🌷 and enjoy them! I may be tucking some extra topples into your winter shares this month too-keep a watch out! 😍 #tulips #wintergrowing #pagrown #flowerhack

Like many others in the US this week: IT’S COLD OUT THERE. We are seeing single digits later in the week and seeing no temps above freezing for the next seven days. This is pretty unusual for us especially in the last couple years, but we are still prepared. Covered all of the plants growing in the hoop house this wkd with Agribon- which adds a layer of insulation to the plants. You might want to add some protection to anything outside that is not quite hardy to your zone or any risky plants, and if you are storing dahlia tubers in a garage or area that ‘usually’ doesn’t freeze-check them and potentially move them. If you haven’t planted your peonies or tulips, get them in the ground ASAP. The ground offers much better insulation than we typically can! Stay warm, all! #flowerfarm #plants #gardening #inmygarden

SNOW! ❄️ When we first moved out here 10 years ago, snow was a lot more commonplace than it has been the last couple years. The last three years, I don’t think we’ve seen a snow that sticks for longer than 24 hours due to our warming location near to DE - and usually it’s just flurries or a light coating or my personal nonfavorite - icy rain😂😂. 

Julian has been asking for a snow day for three years now! Finally today he got his wish- with temps under freezing for a week- the snow will stick around just long enough.

The farm under snow before it is spoiled by feet and wheel tracks is one of my most favorite things. The stark beauty of the trees & our buildings, the stillness of the air-the hushed quiet of the insulation, before plows clean up roads & people start moving again. Enjoying the view outside our sunroom windows today with a good book & the woodstove. Stay cozy, friends ❄️🌸😍 #chestercounty #pagrown #pafarm #brandywinevalley

Tuber sales are no joke.
